questions.text: What is the protein coat covering the nucleic acid in a virion known as?
questions.solution:
The protein coat covering the nucleic acid in a virion is called capsid.

The parts of a virus include: 

  • Nucleocapsid- capsid with enclosed nucleic acid 
  • Tegument- proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid.
  • Envelope- lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation by a budding process through a cellular membrane. 
  • Peplomers- virus-encoded glycoproteins, on the outer surface of the envelope as projections.

 

Characteristics of viruses:

  • Do not have a cellular organization 
  • Have either DNA or RNA but never both
  • Obligate intracellular parasites
  • Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis
  • Filterable
  • Cannot be grown on artificial media
  • Unaffected by antibiotics.

Note : Martinus beijerinck proposed the theory of contagium vivum fluidum (living infectious fluid) while studying the cause of mosaic disease of tobacco plant. He is known as the father of virology.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has a single-stranded DNA?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus has single-stranded DNA. 

All DNA viruses are double-stranded, except parvovirus. (only single-stranded DNA virus)

All RNA viruses have only one copy of single-stranded RNA except:

  • Reovirus- double-stranded RNA virus.
  • Retroviruses- Two copies of single-stranded RNA.

Parvovirus is the smallest DNA virus that infect human beings.

It has a linear, single-stranded RNA genome, enclosed within a core and surrounded by an envelope.

questions.text: A patient in the ICU requires fresh frozen plasma (FFP). The FFP that arrives from the blood bank is labeled as Solvent/Detergent plasma, which destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. Which of the following viral infections is the patient still susceptible to?
questions.solution:
The patient is still susceptible to hepatitis A infection. It is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it’s not affected by SD plasma.

Solvent/Detergent plasma (SD plasma) is a form of blood plasma made from plasma collected from many people which is then processed with solvents in an attempt to remove viruses.

Only the viruses with an envelope are susceptible to SD plasma destruction. Hepatitis B, C, and Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are enveloped.

questions.text: In which of the following viruses is a segmented genome found?
questions.solution:
Segmented genome is found in orthomyxovirus. 

Segmentation of viral genomes allows for the exchange of intact genes between related viruses during coinfection. This recombination is known as reassortment. There is a rearrangement and joining of nucleic acid sequences to form a unique chimeric genome. The new genome is usually less fit than the parent viruses, but occasionally, it results in an evolved virus with increased fitness. 

Examples of segmented viruses (ARBO): 

  • Arenavirus (2 segments)
  • Rotavirus (11 segments)
  • Bunyavirus (3 segments)
  • Orthomyxovirus (8 segments)

questions.text: An epidemic involving an ss-RNA virus with 3'-5' RNA has broken out in West Africa.  Which of the following enzymes do such viruses use in genome replication?
questions.solution:
An ss-RNA with a 3'-5' strand is a negative-stranded RNA. These viruses use RNA replicase or RNA-dependent RNA polymerase during genome replication.

In positive-stranded RNA viruses, the viral RNA itself acts as mRNA.

In negative-stranded RNA viruses, the polarity is opposite that of mRNA. So the genome requires RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize their mRNA.

Examples of negative-stranded RNA viruses (Mnemonic: Always bring da polymerase or fail to replicate):

  • Arenaviruses 
  • Bunyaviruses 
  • Deltaviruses
  • Paramyxoviruses
  • Orthomyxoviruses
  • Filoviruses
  • Rhabdoviruses

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man presents with a complaints of fever, cough and difficulty in breathing for the past 3 days. He gives a history of international travel 10 days back. Laboratory reports show positive for COVID-19. What is the symmetry of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The coronavirus implicated shows an enveloped helical symmetry.

Properties of Coronaviridae family:

  • They are enveloped RNA viruses.
  • They contain a genome of unsegmented single-stranded and positive-sense RNA
  • They have helical nucleocapsid

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding symmetry of viruses ?

choices.text: Viral symmetry is studied by heavy metals stains.
The most efficient closed shell sub-unit arrangement is icosahedral.
Icosahedral symmetry involves 12 faces and 20 vertices .
It is not possible for 'empty' helical particles to form

questions.solution:
Icosahedron has 20 faces (each an equilateral triangle) and 12 vertices.

Option A: Study of viral symmetry by standard electron microscopy requires the use of heavy metal stains (e.g., potassium phosphotungstate) to emphasize surface structure. It is a form of negative staining.

Option B: Symmetry observed with animal viruses is of the icosahedral pattern. It is the most efficient arrangement for subunits in a closed shell. 

Option D: A regular, periodic interaction between capsid protein and nucleic acid is required to maintain a stable helical symmetry. Therefore, it is not possible for empty helical particles to form.

questions.text: An immunologist is working on growing the influenza virus for vaccine production at the National Institute of Virology, Pune. Which of the following sites is used for the given purpose in a fertilized egg?
questions.solution:
Allantoic cavity inoculation (1) is used for the growth and replication of the influenza virus for vaccine production.

Embryonated eggs are used for the cultivation of viruses. 

Note: Both allantoic and amniotic cavity inoculation are recommended for initial isolation of the influenza virus. However, it is simpler to inoculate the virus into the allantoic cavity, as compared to the amniotic cavity, thus allantoic inoculation is the best answer. 

Related Pearl: Cultivation of viruses

  • Suckling mice are used for inoculation of coxsackie and arbovirus

Tissue culture: Cell lines

  • Primary cell lines- Rhesus kidney cell line, Human amniotic cell line, Chick embryo fibroblast
  • Secondary cell lines- Human fibroblast cell line, MRC-5, and WI- 38
  • Continuous cell lines- HeLa cell line, HEp-2, KB, Vero

questions.text: Which virus causes the cytopathic effect of syncytium formation?
questions.solution:
The cytopathic effect of syncytium formation is caused by the measles virus. 

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

Morphological changes in the cells that are caused by viruses are known as cytopathic effects (CPE) and the viruses causing these CPEs are known as cytopathogenic viruses. These CPEs can be detected by a light microscope.

Type of cytopathic effect

Virus

Rapid crenation of cells and degeneration of the cells

Syncytium/multinucleated giant cell formation

Measles, mumps, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

Discrete focal degeneration

Herpes virus

Large granular clumps resembling grapes

Adenovirus

Cytoplasmic vacuolation
